dataset.title: First-flowering dates of plants in the Northern Great Plains

address.deliveryPoint: 218 Stevens Hall Department of Biological Sciences

abstract.para: Phenological observations of plant flowering patterns are a useful tool for studying the ecological impact of global climate change over long term periods. However, the long-term datasets with which meaningful comparisons can be made are rare, especially in the less-populated Northern Great Plains region of North America. Here we present the observations of first flowering time of native and non-native plant species in North Dakota and Minnesota over the course of 51 years in the last century. O.A. Stevens recorded the first-flowering time of 753 species in the vicinity of Fargo, North Dakota and throughout North Dakota from 1910 to 1961. These data offer baseline indications of both the timing of first flowering and the presence/absence for a wide variety of plants in a region of North America with a relatively short growing season.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Area within 15 mile radius of Fargo, ND and greater North Dakota

address.deliveryPoint: 218 Stevens Hall Department of Biological Sciences

section.title: Survey
section.para: Regular observational surveys of flowering plants

description.para: Flowering was observed during the growing season from 1910 to 1961. Data were recorded for herbs, trees and shrubs.

samplingDescription.para: Sampling consisted of visual observations made by Stevens (OAS) on regular field trips during the course of the study. Based on sample dates, field trips were made two or three times per week from April through September, from 1910 to 1961, to sites either within the Fargo vicinity study area or more broadly in North Dakota.
